Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Scott E. Denmark at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign is conducting research to develop a new paradigm for the catalytic, enantioselective dichlorination of alkenes. Addition to unsaturated compounds is among the oldest and most reliable of stereospecific transformations. However, the problem of controlling the absolute configuration of the products has proved challenging. The growing number of complex natural products bearing halogen atoms at stereogenic centers has underscored this critical deficiency in synthetic methodology. This proposal addresses the selectivity challenges inherent in the design of enantioselective dihalogenation processes, and formulates mechanism-based solutions to alkene dihalogenations, including those that circumvent the classical haliranium (or alkene-dihalogen pi-complex) intermediates. Professor Denmark has devised a new approach that inverts the classical "anti" addition to the double bonds by the use of a specially designed catalyst based on selenium. The resulting "syn addition" to double bonds enables the rational development of an enantioselective variant. There are several benefits to society: first in providing a highly skilled workforce to aid in the economic health of our chemistry-based industries. Second, the significance of chemical catalysis cannot be overestimated as it accounts for over 20% of the USA GDP. Given the emphasis on single enantiomer substances in many reaches of the chemical enterprise, new general and selective processes that provide such materials are of great current interest.

The primary objective of this proposal is to construct the mechanistic/physical organic foundation for the development of generally applicable and highly selective alkene dihalogenations reactions using two different modes of catalysis. These two modes constitute the two Specific Aims of this project, namely: (1) redox active main group catalysis and (2) asymmetric phase transfer catalysis. Within each Specific Aim, we are: (1) learning the structure/reactivity correlations and the rules for achieving high catalytic activity (turnover frequencies and turnover numbers) for the target reactions, (2) carrying out detailed mechanistic investigations of the newly invented catalytic reactions, and (3) designing chiral catalysts that impart high stereoselectivity and high chemical conversion for the introduction of new vicinal stereocenters and (4) demonstrating generality in a variety of substrate classes that represent useful and commonly encountered structural motifs. This award supports an excellent training environment for young scientists in the Denmark group.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past three years, we have extensively investigated the enantioselective, vicinal difunctionalization of simple alkenes. The addition of atoms at both ends of a carbon-carbon double bond is arguably the oldest and also most versatile classes of reactions in organic chemistry. The types of different elements, classes of reactions and mechanistic manifolds available to accomplish these transformation are legion. The ability to transform hydrocarbons from feedstock chemicals into functionalized, value added products has enabled the production of countless materials with programmed function and exquisitely defined properties.

To a significant extent, this ability requires the precise control over three key structural features (Figure 1): (1) what is the connectivity of the new atoms attached to the two ends of the double bond (constitutional selectivity), (2) what is the relative disposition of the two atoms in space (diastereoselectivity = topology) and (3) what is absolute disposition of the two atoms in space (enantioselectivity = topography). All three of these features must be exquisitely controlled to provide the target product, efficiently and in high yield.

Traditionally, adding atoms to a carbon-carbon double bond involves the direct attachment of those atoms through myriad mechanisms involving cations, radicals, anions and neutral groups such as in pericyclic reactions. However, in this research  program we developed a new process to add these atoms indirectly, using a phantom group to control the three key features outlined above. This process is called ?redox catalysis? and comes in three variants, isohypsic, oxidative and reductive (Figure 2).

Over the three years of this project, we have engineered an oxidative redox catalytic cycle using chiral organoselenium catalysts to effect the enantioselective addition of two chlorine atoms, two nitrogen atoms, and one nitrogen and one oxygen atom with high constitutional, diastereo- and enantioselectivity (Figure 3). The introduction of these atoms onto simple alkenes in such a highly controlled manner without the need for directing groups or biased substrates highlights the utility of the method. In addition, we have developed a platform for expanding this manifold to the introduction of other atoms such as carbon, sulfur and phosphorus in a similar fashion.

The addition of atoms at both ends of a carbon-carbon double bond is arguably the oldest and also most versatile classes of reactions in organic chemistry. The types of different elements, classes of reactions and mechanistic manifolds available to accomplish these transformation are legion. All three of these features must be exquisitely controlled to provide the target product, efficiently and in high yield.
